1. Limited range: One common criticism of electric cars is their limited driving range compared to gasoline-powered vehicles. Drivers often worry about running out of battery power before reaching a charging station, causing what's known as "range anxiety." Although advancements in technology have helped increase the average range for many electric vehicle models, they still typically fall short compared to gas cars.

2. Charging infrastructure: While there has been growth in public charging stations, availability remains an issue in many areas around the world. Compared to gas cars that can be refueled at any petrol/gas station within minutes, finding a convenient EV charger may not always be so quick and easy.

3. Charging time: Another drawback is the prolonged duration required when recharging your car’s batteries at home or in public charging stations; this can take hours rather than minutes like filling up with fuel.

4. Higher upfront cost: Electric cars are often more expensive upfront than their gasoline counterparts due to high production costs related mainly to battery price points—although they save money on operational costs (maintenance and fuel) over time.

5 .Limited variety of models & designs available - Consumers testing waters might find only limited number of models, trims features and body styles available which suit individual preferences

6.Battery degradation & replacement costs - Lithium-ion batteries tend wear out overtime decreasing overall capacity affecting performance & resale value over longer periods if usage

7.Eco-friendliness debate - Sourcing electricity from fossil fuels or environmentally harmful processes deepens environmental concerns while producing these batteries also raises questions regarding entire carbon footprint claim
